metadata.title: Novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids for electrochemical supercapacitor and water splitting applications

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Vacuum
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/vacuum
Novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids for electrochemical supercapacitor and water splitting applications
B. Jansi Rania, G. Ravia, R. Yuvakkumara,∗, S.I. Hongb,∗∗
aNanomaterials Laboratory, Department of Physics, Alagappa University, Karaikudi, 630 003, Tamil Nadu, India bDepartment of Nanomaterials Engineering, Chungnam National University, Daejeon, 305-764, South Korea
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Novel SmMn2O5 Hollow long nano-cuboids Energy storage Water oxidation
A B S T R A C T
Novel SmMn2O5 hollow long cuboids were synthesized via long time solvothermal route. The structural investigation of orthorhombic phase SmMn2O5 was associated by the predominant peak of (211) crystal plane. In depth analysis of band structure have been explored by the strong absorbance edge around 380 nm in UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) spectra and the calculated energy band gap was 3.22 eV from Tauc plot. The intensive investigation of electrochemical performance of novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids were revealed from cyclic voltammogram and the specific capacitance obtained was 256 F/g at 5mV/s scan rate. The water oxidizing ability of the fabricated SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids electrode was examined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) study at the maximum current density of 0.37mA/g. The internal resistance (Rs) and the charge transfer resistance (Rct) were respectively reported as 13 and 355Ω with low Tafel slope value of 64 mV/dec. The stability of the fabricated novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboid electrode was investigated through chronoamperometry (CA) study for 3 h with 100% retention of water oxidizing ability.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, the world has developed a growth of technologies and advancement of electronic devices as an alternate of fossil fuels for energy production and storage applications [1,2]. The sustainable energy is the key factor to take over the world towards full filled and sufficient technology development. To produce clean energy, one of the promising approaches is water splitting which can be achieved either by electrochemical or photoelectrochemical or photocatalytic path way [3,4]. Auxiliary, the energy storage device fabrication is another one of the hot demand research topics among the young researchers and therefore the supercapacitors application is one of the research trends in energy storage fields. Hence, in the present study, we have focused the electrolysis of water through electrochemical water splitting approach which could definitely be an efficient energy production method for next generation energy production. Generally, manganese based nanomaterials are inevitably utilized as potential materials for multiple applications due to its abundance, low cost, chemical stability and physical and electronic properties etc [5–7]. Novel combinations of metals with manganese based oxides played an important role in the field of energy storage devices due to its non toxic nature and resistance to charging and discharging behavior [8–10]. In such a way that, a new
family of mullite oxides such as SmMn2O5 is grasped by researchers due to its efficient adaptation in various fields like oxygen production, oxygen reduction, CO oxidation, battery applications etc [11–13]. This novel kind of oxide is unique in its electronic structure initiated by the coexistence of both octahedral (Mn4+) and pyramidal (Mn3+) crystal structure which provided an easy accessible oxygen related reactions [14]. Moreover, the shape controlled mullite oxide catalyzing the overall reaction kinetics and furthermore, SmMn2O5 hollow long nanocuboids (HLNCs) catalyzing the electrochemical water splitting reaction has not yet been revealed by the researchers. The required diverse morphology has been achieved by many different approaches such as sol-gel, co-precipitation, ball milling, combustion method etc. Among them, we have followed the hydrothermal route due to its list of advantages such as faster growth reaction, pure phase, good quality material synthesis, desired morphology production in controlled size by controlled growth rate, user friendly, low cost and eco friendly nature [15]. Therefore, we have been explored the synthesis of novel long hollow cuboidal nanostructures via one pot hydrothermal method by tuning the synthesis parameter of pro-longed treatment time. The advantages of long treatment time solvothermal route has been explored to synthesize and optimize mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs in order to obtain the unique morphology with controlled particle size with good
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vacuum.2019.05.029 Received 29 December 2018; Received in revised form 19 May 2019; Accepted 20 May 2019

Vacuum 166 (2019) 279–285
Available online 21 May 2019 0042-207X/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
crystalline nature of pure phase material for supercapacitor and water splitting applications. In addition, the hollow nanostructures generally played an important role in electrochemical reaction by providing an extremely improved ion transportation kinetics, rapid reaction mechanism, and superior structural stability with enhanced conductivity over the entire electrochemical reaction [16,17].
The morphology dependent electrochemical behavior of the material played an important role in all the electrochemical potential applications. Hence, the synthesis of one dimensional nanostructures such as nanorods, nanowires and nano needles [18] etc, two dimensional nanostructures such as nano plates, nano discs, nano coins, nano flakes [19] etc, hierarchical three dimensional nanostructures such as nano flowers, nano urchin like structures [20] etc are dedicated its superior performance in vast area of applications such as supercapacitors [21], batteries [22], sensors [23] and water splitting [24] etc. Therefore, in the present study, we have synthesized novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids via template free, long time hydrothermal method. Mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs have been synthesized due to its peculiar crystalline structure such as pyramid and octahedral which will be contributed more in electrochemical reaction especially those Mn4+ and Mn3+ crystal structures are the major factors in catalyzing the oxygen related reactions effectively and furthermore it possessed good storage mechanism during redox reaction. Further, introducing oxygen vacancies and novel HLNCs nanostructures were successfully attempted to improve the electrochemical performance of the obtained products. Furthermore, this kind of mullite HLNCs for electrochemical OER activity is yet to be explored by the research community. Hence, the electrochemical function of the synthesized material designed for energy storage and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the long time stability under continuous electrochemical reaction has been revealed by using half-cell measurement in 1M KOH alkaline electrolyte solution. The synthesized SmMn2O5 HLNCs coated on glassy carbon electrode (GCE) is used are working electrode, platinum wire as counter electrode and Ag/AgCl as reference electrode.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text:
All the chemical re-agents such as Sm(NO3)3·6H2O, KMnO4, Mn (CH3COO)2·6H2O, absolute ethanol, deionized water and KOH were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. At first, 0.1M Sm (NO3)3·6H2O + 0.05M KMnO4 + 0.1M Mn(CH3COO)2·6H2O were dissolved in 100ml of deionized water under constant stirring of 550 rpm for 2 h. Then, 2M KOH solutions was dissolved in 100ml of deionized water and poured into the above solution dropwise with burette. After, 3 h of stirring, the homogeneous solution was obtained which was replaced in Teflon lined 250ml autoclave at 180 °C for 48 h. The final product was washed with absolute ethanol and water and then dried in hot air oven for 12 h and was then given for further characterization. X'pert PRO analytical diffractometer using CuKα as radiation (1.541 Å) source was used for structural characterization. Imaging Spectrograph STR 500 nm focal length laser micro Raman spectrometer SEKI, Japan was used for Raman analysis. Photoluminescence (PL) spectrum was explored by using Varian Cary Eclipse Photoluminescence Spectrometer. Infrared (IR) spectra were analyzed using Thermo Nicolet 380. The morphological studies were investigated by Scanning Electron Microscope (ZEISS-V80). The optical band gap of the materials was estimated by Varian Cary 5 E UV/VISNIR UV–visible spectrophotometer. The electrochemical performance of SmMn2O5 HLNCs towards energy storage and OER activity was examined in a conventional three electrode electrochemical cell in 1M KOH alkaline electrolyte solution at room temperature by using Biologic SP 150 work station. Initially, glassy carbon electrode (GCE) was cleaned by using 50 μm Alumina powder with deionized water and then ultrasonicated for 2min to get rid of all the impurities from GCE. Then, 1mg of SmMn2O5 HLNCs was dispersed in 1ml of ethanol under ultrasonication for 15min. After, getting homogeneous mixture, it was
drop casted on cleaned GCE with 10 μl pipette. Approximately, 10 μg of SmMn2O5 HLNCs was loaded on 3mm diameter GCE. It was left for 24 h at room temperature for natural drying process. Then, the electrochemical function of the material was tested with cyclic voltammogram (CV) study, galvanostatic charging and discharging (GCD), linear sweep voltammogram (LSV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and chronamperometry (CA) study.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The novel SmMn2O5 HLNCs have been synthesized via long time solvothermal route. The obtained nano-cuboids have been thoroughly analyzed and confirmed by XRD spectrum as shown in Fig. 1. The orthorhombic phase of SmMn2O5 nano-cuboids are revealed by the sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 15.5, 23.9, 26.2, 28.7, 30.6, 31.4, 33.5, 35.3, 37.9, 41.3, 46.8, 48.9, 50.2, 51.7, 53.7, 55.3, 59.3, 65.5, 68.8 and 75.6° related to the crystal planes of (001), (120), (210), (201), (211), (002), (130), (112), (022), (212), (141), (240), (410), (401), (420), (213), (402), (004), (521) and (134) respectively. These sharp resolved diffraction peaks agreed with the standard JCPDS card number #88–0374 of orthorhombic mullite SmMn2O5 nanostructures. The good crystalline, pure mullite SmMn2O4 phase HLNCs achieved in our work was revealed by sharp, resolved diffraction peaks obtained from XRD spectrum. The average crystallite size of the synthesized mullite oxide has been calculated from Debye-Scherrer formula; D=0.9λ/βcosθ; where λ is X-ray wavelength, β the full width at half maximum intensity and θ the Bragg's angle [25]. The average crystallite size is estimated as 55.83 nm. The estimated average dislocation density of the product is about 0.000321 E+10 Lines/m2 from the formula; S= 1/D2, where D is size of crystallites [26]. The smaller changes observed in diffraction angles when compared to standard JCPDS diffraction angles may be due to the observation of micro strain present in the sample due to prolonged treatment time which was calculated as 0.1910 from the formula υ= βcosθ/4, where β is full width at half maximum and θ the Bragg's angle [27]. Hence, XRD spectrum of synthesized mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs revealed the complete information about the structural properties such as crystallite size, dislocation density and micro strain. Furthermore, it is reported that the formation of good quality, pure phase and good crystalline SmMn2O5 is achieved by prolonged hydrothermal treatment at optimum temperature and pressure condition. The following Table 1 showed the structural parameters of the synthesized SmMn2O5 HLNCs.
Fig. 2 demonstrated the Raman spectrum of the mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs with strong signature of two phonon vibration peaks around 612 and 663 cm−1 which could be attributed to the Mn–O stretching vibrations of orthorhombic SmMn2O5 [28]. In precise, the strong peak
around 612 cm−1 could be ascribed to the Mn–O vibration of MnO6 octahedral site of orthorhombic SmMn2O5 perovskite nanostructures [29] and the peak around 663 cm−1 could be ascribed to the symmetric stretching vibration of Mn2O3 phase [30] originated due to high pressure maintenance of prolonged reaction time. Hence, the intrinsic phonon vibration mode of synthesized orthorhombic SmMn2O5 HLNCs is confirmed from Raman spectrum.
The emission behavior, electron trapping nature and the intrinsic defects present in the sample has been characterized by PL spectrum as shown in Fig. 3. The sample was excited by the wavelength 320 nm and then three predominant emission peaks were observed in the region of 359, 493 and 531 nm. The observed peak around 359 nm could be ascribed to the near band edge (NBE) emission of semiconductor materials. The observed band around 493 and 531 nm could be attributed to the intrinsic defects and oxygen vacancies in the form of defects present
in the sample respectively. Hence, it replicated the formation of SmMn2O5 HLNCs consisted of intrinsic and oxygen defects which will help the electrochemical performance of the sample. The role of oxygen defects is inevitable in electrochemical reactions by increasing the conductivity thereby providing the rapid electronic mobility which results the improved electrochemical storage and catalyzing activity of the sample achieved [31]. The corresponding optical band gaps of the sample were calculated as 3.45, 2.51 and 2.33 eV for 359, 493 and 531 nm respectively. The calculated band gaps are depending on the emission peaks for the corresponding excitation wavelength. Hence, PL spectrum of obtained orthorhombic SmMn2O5 HLNCs clearly illustrated the detailed information about the oxygen defects present in the sample and its role in enhancing the electrochemical performance.
FTIR spectrum of the synthesized orthorhombic SmMn2O5 HLNCs replicated the metal oxygen vibrations present in the samples as shown in Fig. 4 in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. The observed band about 480 cm−1 could be ascribed to the bending vibration of MnO6 present in orthorhombic SmMn2O5 HLNCs [32]. The observed peaks around 548 and 641 cm−1 could be ascribed to asymmetric stretching vibration of MnO6 in SmMn2O5 HLNCs [33]. These three bands in finger print region present in the synthesized sample confirmed the metal oxygen vibrations of SmMn2O5 HLNCs. The other bands observed in characteristic region around 1645 and 3425 cm−1 could be ascribed to OH bending and OH stretching vibrations respectively [34]. Hence, the formation of orthorhombic phase SmMn2O5 HLNCs has been confirmed moreover by FTIR spectrum. Generally, SmMn2O5 nanostructures possessed good vibrational properties due to the stretching and bending of MnO6 present in SmMn2O5 nanostructures. Optimum vibration property depends on the quality of the material in addition to the corresponding morphology. According to SmMn2O5 nanostructures, it provide good vibration property for all kind of morphology but good quality and crystalline nature of the sample provide strong deep and optimum vibration bands. Further, agglomeration of morphology and very small particle size led to crystal defects in the lattice, since the agglomerated morphology of the nanostructures suppress the vibrational property [35]. Hence, the prepared sample with good crystalline nature provide optimum vibration band in FTIR study.
Fig. 5 evidenced the formation of mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs from SEM images at different scale and magnification ranges. Fig. 5a represented the surface morphology of long cuboids at 1 μm (18 KX) scale range. It denoted the formation of cuboids with approximately 1 μm length and 200 nm width. It seems like long cuboid structure formation. Good dispersive nature and strong cuboidal signature assessed by the material is due to long growth time under optimized temperature and pressure maintenance in the autoclave. Fig. 5b represented the clear
Table 1 XRD data and calculated structural parameters of SmMn2O5 HLNCs.
2θ (deg) FWHM [°2Th.] Parameters Values
36.5 0.1476 Crystallite size 55.83 nm Dislocation density 0.000321 E+10 Lines/m2
Micro strain 0.1910
Fig. 2. Raman spectrum of mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs.
view of hollow cuboid formation by the breakage of cuboid edges (denoted by dotted arrows). The breakage of some of the cuboids may be due to the long time treatment of material to achieve desired shape and size. Fig. 5c represented the typical HLNCs with compact, uniform and highly distinguished structure with approximate aspect ratio of ∼200 nm wide and ∼900 nm length long cuboids of hollow nature.
UV vis DRS spectrum of mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs is as shown in Fig. 6a. It reflected the optical behavior of the synthesized sample in between the wavelength region of 200–800 nm. The clear cut absorption edge has been obtained around 380 nm. It has driven the Tauc plot as shown in Fig. 6b to estimate the band gap value from the formula; αhυ=A(hυ-Eg)n, where α, h, A, and Eg denoted the absorption coefficient, incident photon energy, constant, and band gap energy respectively. The value of n denoted the type of transition, i.e., n=2 for direct and 2/3 for direct forbidden, 1/2 for indirect allowed and 1/3 for indirect forbidden transition respectively. The indirect band gap energy of synthesized mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs has been approximated as 3.22 eV from Tauc plot as shown in Fig. 6b, which will be more adaptable to the electrochemical behavior of the sample during entire electrochemical redox and water splitting reactions.
The electrochemical behavior of the sample has been thoroughly analyzed in half-cell electrochemical set up by fabricating the
synthesized mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs as a working electrode as shown in Fig. 7a. As the initial measurement of electrochemical process, CV study has been run for the fabricated electrode in between the potential window from 0 to 0.6 V V Ag/AgCl. CV study has been carried out for different scan rates such as 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35 and 40mV respectively. Generally, the specific capacitance calculation is believed to estimate the catalyzing ability of the electrode towards oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The electrode which possessed good specific capacitance and current density is suggested to have good OER activity in electrochemical water splitting process. The specific capacitance of the fabricated electrode has been calculated from the formula;
= ∫ − C IdVms V V( 2 1) , IdVwhere denoted integral sweep area from the CV curve, m denoted the mass of SmMn2O4 loaded on GCE, s denoted the scan rate fixed. The calculated specific capacitance values are 256, 243, 229, 215, 203, 201, 197 and 186 F/g for 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35 and 40mV/s scan rates respectively and are listed in Table 2. The dispersive, compact long nano-cuboids provided more active sites for succeeding the electrochemical reaction and also the oxygen defects present in the sample and provided more conductivity for faster electrochemical reaction which further supported the overall electrochemical performance of the fabricated electrode.
EIS spectrum of the synthesized mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs with
corresponding equivalent circuit has been illustrated in Fig. 7b. This Nyquist plot has been run in between the frequency range from 100mHz to 100 kHz. The fitted image of the Nyquist plot for the equivalent circuit has been provided in the inserted image format as shown in Fig. 7B. The two regions are called as the charge transfer resistance region (depressed semi-circle shown in the inserted image) and the Warburg conductive (spike) region. The solution (internal) resistance Rs of 13Ω and the charge transfer resistance Rct of 355Ω have been estimated from EIS spectra which provided the clear view of fast charge transfer and electronic mobility. The shape of the Nyquist plot clearly revealed the rapid electron transfer kinetics and diffusive behavior of the fabricated electrode [36]. The angle spike region
approximately noted as 45° which meant that the active material could be easily diffused in the electrode/electrolyte interface during electrochemical reaction. Further, this kind of good conductive nature of the fabricated mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs may due to the presence of oxygen defects and organized nano-cuboidal morphology.
Fig. 7c illustrated the galvanostatic charging and discharging of fabricated mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs electrode at different current densities such as 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 A/g respectively in between the potential window of 0–0.5 V. GCD curve clearly demonstrated the homogeneity of charging and discharging pattern of SmMn2O5 HLNCs which may be caused for higher current density value possessed by the electrode. Further, the specific capacitance calculated from GCD curve is 141 F/g at 1 A/g and is a very good achievement of fabricated SmMn2O5 HLNCs electrode in storage mechanism. This higher specific capacitance is resulted due to the HLNCs morphology, good ionic conductivity, faster charge transfer and excellent charging-discharging coherence of SmMn2O5 electrode.
The OER activity of the electrode has been analyzed by LSV run at 10mV/s scan rate in between the potential window of −0.2–1 V V Ag/ AgCl as shown in Fig. 7d. The oxygen is evolved at the potential of 0.58 V and the continuous evolution of OER up to 1 V has been recorded. The current density achieved for the fabricated mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs electrode was 0.37mA/g. The water splitting half reaction of 2H2O+4 h+→O2+4H+(1.23 V Vs. RHE) has been succeeded by the electrode by the synergistic effect of compact hollow nano-cuboid morphology, oxygen vacancies and faster electronic mobility etc. Hollow nature of long nano-cuboids will make ease of electrochemical path way by providing the superior structural and electrochemical stability in accordance with the faster charge transportation mechanism. Moreover, the fabricated electrode exhibited OER activity at moderate over potential of 360mV which showed the good water oxidizing ability of the electrode that may be caused by the favorable HLNCs morphology to provide easy path way for more interaction between electrode active sites and electrolyte ions during electrochemical reaction. Further, the nano range size of HLNCs provided more number of active site at electrode/electrolyte interface whereas good conductivity and ionic mobility of the electrode and nano
sized morphology of synthesized SmMn2O5 HLNCs facilitated good OER activity of the electrode and also the activity has been compared with literature as shown in Table 3. The prepared SmMn2O5 nanostructures for supercapacitor and electrochemical water splitting applications have not been explored yet. Therefore, the activity of our electrode has been compared with Mn and Sm based nanostructures for electrochemical supercapacitor applications reported by literature in Table 3.
Fig. 8a showed the Tafel slope value of the fabricated mullite electrode. Generally, smaller the Tafel slope value caused the increased charge transfer kinetics of electrode. From Tafel slope value, the rate limiting property of the electrode could be estimated to investigate its conductivity under electrochemical reaction. The slope value calculated from Tafel plot for our fabricated electrode is 64 mV/dec and indicated as the first rate limiting factor of the electron transfer [3]. This small Tafel slope value is evidently supported the results obtained from EIS spectra as the improved charge transfer and higher conductivity possessed by the electrode.
The stability of the fabricated electrode has been revealed by CA test at 360mV/s over-potential for 3 h under continuous OER activity as shown in Fig. 8b. The obtained current density from CA study was 0.086mA/g with 100% retention in its electrochemical OER activity and could be useful for electrochemical water splitting applications. The obtained current density in the present study is lower which may be due to many factors such as synthesis condition, calcination process etc. In this work, we tried to optimize the synthesis process to obtain the controlled morphology of HLNCs and also revealed the role of morphology and oxygen defects on physical and electrochemical properties. We will try to achieve higher current density in our future works by further controlling the synthesis process optimization and composite materials formation. Moreover, the current density and specific capacitance value will be enhanced further by adding graphene based materials with mullite phase nanostructures and further optimization of synthesis condition to obtain rGO@SmMn2O5 with diverse morphology has been explored in future works.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: Novel mullite SmMn2O5 HLNCs has been synthesized via simple prolonged hydrothermal route and the electrode has been fabricated on GCE successfully which was subjected in electrochemical half-cell set up. The improved specific capacitance of 141 F/g current density at 1 A/g current density was achieved by GCD study. The OER activity of the electrode has been achieved as 0.37mA/g at 10mV/s scan rate. The 100% catalyzing activity of the fabricated electrode after 3 h of electrochemical reaction was reported with high electronic mobility.

metadata.abstractText: Novel SmMn2O5 hollow long cuboids were synthesized via long time solvothermal route. The structural investigation of orthorhombic phase SmMn2O5 was associated by the predominant peak of (211) crystal plane. In depth analysis of band structure have been explored by the strong absorbance edge around 380 nm in UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) spectra and the calculated energy band gap was 3.22 eV from Tauc plot. The intensive investigation of electrochemical performance of novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids were revealed from cyclic voltammogram and the specific capacitance obtained was 256 F/g at 5mV/s scan rate. The water oxidizing ability of the fabricated SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboids electrode was examined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) study at the maximum current density of 0.37mA/g. The internal resistance (Rs) and the charge transfer resistance (Rct) were respectively reported as 13 and 355Ω with low Tafel slope value of 64 mV/dec. The stability of the fabricated novel SmMn2O5 hollow long nano-cuboid electrode was investigated through chronoamperometry (CA) study for 3 h with 100% retention of water oxidizing ability.
